content.question: The QNH at an airfield located at mean sea level is 1022 hPa. The air temperature is not available. What is the QFF?

options.C: It is not possible to give a definitive answer.

key_points: QNH = The atmospheric pressure adjusted to mean sea-level
If you are on the ground at an airport and turn in the local QNH at your altimeter’s subscale, it will display the airports altitude above mean sea level
QFE = The pressure set on the altimeter so that it indicates the height above the reference elevation being used (height above current ground level)
learning.explanation: QNH = The atmospheric pressure adjusted to mean sea-level. If you are on the ground at an airport and turn in the local QNH at your altimeter’s subscale, it will display the airports altitude above mean sea level. QFE = The pressure set on the altimeter so that it indicates the height above the reference elevation being used (height above current ground level). If you set the QFE on your altimeter’s subscale on the ground, the altimeter would read 0 feet. So, it is used to get to know the height above the ground. QNE =The indicated altitude at the landing runway threshold when 1013,25 is set in the altimeter’s subscale. In other words, it is the pressure altitude at the landing runway threshold. QFF = Mean sea level pressure, derived by taking into account the actual temperature conditions. So, the QFE reduced to mean sea level with regard to the actual outside air temperature. In case of this specific question: QFF is effectively the pressure measured at a specific datum (airfield, meteorological station etc) adjusted to sea level using the actual conditions occurring at the time. If you had the QFF set and landed on the sea your altimeter would read zero. QNH is the pressure measured at a specific datum (airfield, meteorological station etc) adjusted to sea level using the lapse rates etc of the International Standard Atmosphere. If you had the QNH set then at the airfield your altimeter would read the elevation of the airfield and if you landed on the sea it would only read zero if the actual conditions were the same as the ISA conditions ( that is if QNH=QFF). The question states that an airfield is located at mean sea level. Because of this there is no need for any temperature corrections because the airfield does not have any elevation. Thus, will the QNH be the same as the QFF and the same as the QFE.

content.question: Average seasonal tropopause heights are approximately:

options.A: latitude 55°N: FL250 in winter, FL350 in summer.
options.B: latitude 25°N: FL500 in winter, FL250 in summer.
options.C: latitude 55°N: FL500 in winter, FL250 in summer.
options.D: latitude 55°N: FL250 in winter, FL400 in summer.

key_points: Learning Objective 050
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 050.01.01.02.04: Describe the variations of the FL and temperature of the tropopause from the poles to the equator. The atmosphere is split up into many different layers. The lowest layer is the troposphere, followed by the stratosphere. In general, these are the two that pilots care about most. The top of the troposphere is called the tropopause, and is where the stratosphere begins. The atmosphere is not always the same height though, in fact it varies wildly in height between the tropics and the poles. Over the equator, the atmosphere is very tall, due to both heat (meaning that pressure reduces at a lower rate with altitude) and other effects such as convection and general circulation of air. The atmosphere over the poles has much less height, this is mostly to do with the reduced convection and the cold air, which loses pressure more quickly with altitude. The height of the troposphere (which is indicative of the atmosphere in general) will therefore change from season to season, as solar heating differs due to the angle of the sun to the ground. In the winter season, in general a hemisphere will have a lower tropopause, and in the summer, a higher tropopause. This also coincides with how close a particular place is to the ITCZ, the heat equator, which moves with the seasons. In the tropics, the tropopause reaches around FL550 in summer, dropping a little in the winter, depending on where in the tropics. At the poles, it can drop to as low as FL200 around the winter time, and up to around FL250 in the summer. The ISA (International Standard Atmosphere) has the tropopause at 36 090 ft, which is a good average for areas at 40-50º Latitude (above this in summer, below it in winter). Therefore FL250 to FL350 sounds plausible for 55º N, which equates to the South of Scotland, or around the latitude of Denmark. Note: You only need a rough idea of tropopause heights for this question (especially as two answers can be removed for having higher winter heights than summer heights, which is not correct) and the learning objective above is vague, but does not require memorizing a table or any such deep knowledge.

content.question: How is the heat of the Earth predominantly transferred upwards and exits the atmosphere?

key_points: Insolation The Sun provides the energy that heats the Earth and its atmosphere by a process of insolation (incoming solar radiation)
Approximately half of the total radiation reaches, and is absorbed by, the Earth’s surface with the rest being absorbed by the atmosphere or re-radiated into space by scattering and reflection
Terrestrial Radiation The Earth radiates energy into the atmosphere in the form of terrestrial radiation
learning.explanation: Insolation The Sun provides the energy that heats the Earth and its atmosphere by a process of insolation (incoming solar radiation). Approximately half of the total radiation reaches, and is absorbed by, the Earth’s surface with the rest being absorbed by the atmosphere or re-radiated into space by scattering and reflection. Terrestrial Radiation The Earth radiates energy into the atmosphere in the form of terrestrial radiation. It is more readily absorbed by the atmosphere especially by clouds, water vapour and carbon dioxide that solar radiation due to its longer wavelength. The absorption of heat by the atmosphere from the Earth is the main heat exchange mechanism that causes weather. Any terrestrial radiation not absorbed or reflected by the atmosphere escapes back into space. SUMMARY Insolation: sun warms the Earth; Radiation: Earth loses heat, radiates heat. During the day, insolation predominates over radiation; hence Earth gets warmer. At night, radiation predominates; Earth cools down. On the average, however, (within a year) insolation and radiation are approximately in balance but it fluctuates during a year (seasonal).

Learning Objective 050.01.02.06.01: Explain the cooling/warming of the surface of the Earth by radiation. Insolation The Sun emits electromagnetic waves of many different wavelengths, and the vast majority of the energy comes in the form of short wavelength (high frequency) radiation. This does not heat the atmosphere directly. We can refer to this short-wave radiation as ultraviolet (UV), as that is what makes up quite a lot of it. The UV rays are somewhat absorbed by ozone in the upper atmosphere, reflected off clouds back into space, and the rays which are reach the ground either are reflected or absorbed by the ground (approximately half of the incoming radiation is absorbed). This heats the ground, which then produces much lower frequency (longer wavelength) infrared radiation, heating the air in the atmosphere via infrared radiation, conduction and convection. Therefore, for this question, the short-wave radiation from The Sun heats the Earth, and the Earth loses it's heat through long-wave radiation (amongst other forms of heat loss).

content.question: What gas in the atmosphere can cause inflight problems (chest, breathing-throat)?

key_points: OZONE HEALTH EFFECTS Most atmospheric ozone is concentrated in a layer in the Stratosphere
Aircraft flying above the Tropopause may, therefore, be flying through air with high concentrations of Ozone
Ozone is poisonous and, in high enough concentrations, when breathed in, can cause headaches, irritation to the respiratory system, and can harm lung function
learning.explanation: OZONE HEALTH EFFECTS Most atmospheric ozone is concentrated in a layer in the Stratosphere. Aircraft flying above the Tropopause may, therefore, be flying through air with high concentrations of Ozone. Ozone is poisonous and, in high enough concentrations, when breathed in, can cause headaches, irritation to the respiratory system, and can harm lung function. This can cause chest pain, coughing, shortness of breath, and throat irritation Catalytic converters are fitted to the aircraft air conditioning systems on most modern aircraft to break down the Ozone into harmless Oxygen.
